1.verse: This is the ·message [oracle; burden] for the city of Nineveh [the capital of the Assyrian empire]. This is the book of the vision of Nahum, ·who was from the town of Elkosh [the Elkoshite; of uncertain location].

2.verse: The Lord Is Angry with Nineveh - The LORD is a ·jealous [zealous] God [Ex. 20:5; 34:14; Deut. 4:24; 5:9; Josh. 24:19] who ·punishes [avenges]; the LORD ·punishes [avenges] and is filled with ·anger [wrath]. The LORD ·punishes [takes vengeance on] ·those who are against him [his adversaries/enemies], and he ·stays angry with [or vents his wrath against] his enemies.

3.verse: The LORD ·does not become angry quickly [is slow to anger; Ex. 34:6; Num. 14:18; Neh. 9:17; Ps. 86:15; 145:8; Joel 2:13; Jon. 4:2], and his power is great. The LORD will not let the guilty go unpunished. ·Where the LORD goes, there are [His way/path is in] whirlwinds and storms, and the clouds are the dust beneath his feet [God’s awesome power is seen in nature; the clouds are his chariot; Ps. 68:4; 104:3; Dan. 7:13; Matt. 24:30; 26:64; Rev. 1:7].

4.verse: He ·speaks to [rebukes] the sea and makes it dry [Ps. 106:9; Matt. 8:26; Luke 8:24]; he dries up all the rivers. The areas of Bashan and Carmel dry up, and the ·flowers [blossoms] of Lebanon dry up [areas known for their lush vegetation and fertile land].

5.verse: The mountains ·shake [tremble] in front of him, and the hills melt. The earth ·trembles [heaves] ·when he comes [before him], the world and all who live in it.

6.verse: ·No one [Who…?] can ·stay alive [withstand/stand before] ·when he is angry [his indignation/anger]; no one can ·survive [endure] his ·strong [fierce; burning] anger. His ·anger [wrath] is poured out like fire; the rocks ·are smashed by [crumble before] him.

7.verse: The LORD is good, ·giving protection [a stronghold; refuge] in ·times [the day] of trouble. He ·knows [cares for] those who trust in him.

8.verse: But like a ·rushing [overwhelming] flood, he will ·completely destroy [make an end of] ·Nineveh [her place; Nineveh was destroyed in 612 BC, after Nahum wrote]; he will ·chase [pursue] his enemies ·until he kills them [into darkness].

9.verse: The LORD will completely destroy ·anyone making plans [or whatever you plot/conspire] against him. Trouble will not come a second time.

10.verse: Those people will be ·like tangled [or entangled among] thorns or like people drunk from their wine; they will be ·burned up quickly [consumed] like ·dry weeds [stubble].

11.verse: Someone has come from ·Nineveh [you] who ·makes evil plans [plots evil] against the LORD and gives wicked ·advice [counsel; strategy].

12.verse: This is what the LORD says: “Although Assyria ·is strong [or has allies] and has many people, it will be ·defeated [destroyed] and ·brought to an end [pass away]. Although I have ·made you suffer, Judah [afflicted you], I will ·make you suffer [afflict you] no more.

13.verse: Now I will ·free you from their control [break his yoke from you] and tear away your ·chains [shackles].”

14.verse: The LORD has given you this command, Nineveh: “You will not have ·descendants [seed] to carry on your name. I will ·destroy [cut off] the ·idols [carved images] and metal images that are in the ·temple [house] of your gods. I will ·make [prepare] a grave for you, because you are ·wicked [vile; despicable].”

15.verse: Look, there on the ·hills [mountains], ·someone is [the feet of one] bringing good news [Is. 52:7]! He is announcing peace! Celebrate your ·feasts [festivals], people of Judah, and ·give your promised sacrifices to God [fulfill your vows]. The wicked will not come to attack you again; they have been completely ·destroyed [cut off].

1.verse: Nineveh Will Be Defeated - The ·destroyer [attacker; scatterer] is coming ·to attack [against] ·you, Nineveh [you; the Babylonians and Medes destroyed Nineveh]. Guard the ·defenses [fortress; ramparts]. Watch the road. ·Get ready [Gird your loins]. Gather all your strength!

2.verse: ·Destroyers [Plunderers] have ·destroyed [plundered] God’s people and ruined their vines, but the LORD will ·bring back [restore] Jacob’s ·greatness [splendor; majesty] like Israel’s ·greatness [splendor; majesty].

3.verse: The shields of his soldiers are red [either dyed red or splattered with blood]; the army is dressed in ·red [scarlet]. The metal on the chariots ·flashes like fire [shines; glistens] ·when [on the day] they are ready to attack; ·their horses are excited [or their cypress spears are brandished].

4.verse: The chariots ·race [storm; charge insanely] through the streets and rush back and forth through the city squares. They look like torches; they run like lightning.

5.verse: He [probably the king of Assyria] ·calls [or remembers] his officers, but they stumble on the way. They hurry to the city wall, and the ·shield [or siege tower] is put into place.

6.verse: The river gates are thrown open, and the palace ·is destroyed [collapses; dissolves; melts].

7.verse: It has been ·announced [decreed] that ·the people of Nineveh [she] will be ·captured [exiled; or stripped; exposed] and carried away. The slave girls moan like doves and beat their breasts [a sign of grief].

8.verse: Nineveh is like a pool, and now its water is draining away. “Stop! Stop!” the people yell, but no one turns back.

9.verse: ·Take [Plunder] the silver! ·Take [Plunder] the gold! There is no end to the treasure— piles of wealth of every ·kind [precious/desirable thing].

10.verse: ·Nineveh is robbed [Empty!], ·ruined [desolate!], and destroyed. ·The people lose their courage [Their hearts melt], and their knees knock. ·Stomachs ache [Bodies/Loins in anguish], and everyone’s face grows pale.

11.verse: Where is the lions’ den [the lion was a symbol of Assyria] and the place where they feed their young? Where did the lion, lioness, and cubs go without being afraid?

12.verse: The lion killed enough for his cubs, ·enough [and strangled prey] for his ·mate [lionesses]. He filled his cave with ·the animals he caught [prey]; he filled his den with ·meat he had killed [torn (flesh)].

13.verse: “I am against ·you, Nineveh [you],” says the LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts]. “I will burn up your chariots in smoke, and the sword will ·kill [devour] your young lions. I will ·stop you from hunting down others on [cut off your prey from] the earth, and your messengers’ voices will no longer be heard.”

1.verse: It Will Be Terrible for Nineveh - ·How terrible it will be for [Woe to] the city ·that has killed so many [of blood]. It is full of lies and ·goods stolen from other countries [plunder]. It is ·always killing somebody [never empty of prey].

2.verse: Hear the sound of whips and the ·noise [rumble; shaking] of the wheels. Hear horses galloping and chariots bouncing along!

3.verse: ·Horses [Cavalry; Horsemen] are charging, swords are ·shining [flashing], spears are gleaming! Many are ·dead [slain]; their bodies are piled up— too many to count. People stumble over the dead bodies.

4.verse: ·The city was like a prostitute [For her many acts of prostitution]; she was ·charming [graceful] and a ·lover of magic [mistress of sorceries]. She made nations slaves with her prostitution and her ·witchcraft [sorcery; charms].

5.verse: “I am against ·you, Nineveh [you],” says the LORD ·All-Powerful [Almighty; of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts]. “I will pull your dress up over your face and show the nations your nakedness and the kingdoms your shame [the punishment of a prostitute in the ancient Near East].

6.verse: I will throw filthy garbage on you and ·make a fool of you [treat you with contempt]. I will make ·people stare at you [you a spectacle].

7.verse: Everyone who sees you will ·run away [or turn away in disgust] and say, ‘Nineveh is in ruins. Who will ·cry [grieve; lament] for her?’ Nineveh, where will I find anyone to comfort you?”

8.verse: You are no better than ·Thebes [No Amon; meaning “city of (the god) Amon”; This capital of Upper Egypt, thought to be impregnable, was destroyed by the Assyrians in 663 BC], who sits by the Nile River with water all around her. The river was her ·defense [rampart]; the waters were like a wall around her.

9.verse: Cush [ancient Ethiopia or Nubia] and Egypt gave her endless strength; Put and Libya supported her [neighboring countries allied with Egypt].

10.verse: But Thebes was captured and went into ·captivity [exile]. Her ·small children [infants] were ·beaten to death [dashed to pieces] at every street corner. Lots were thrown for her ·important men [nobles; parceled out as slaves], and all of her ·leaders [great ones] were put in chains.

11.verse: You [Nineveh] will be drunk, too. You will hide; you will ·look for a place safe [seek refuge] from the enemy.

12.verse: All your ·defenses [fortresses] are like fig trees with ripe fruit. When the tree is shaken, the figs fall into the mouth of the eater.

13.verse: Look at your soldiers. They are all women [meaning helpless or physically weak]! The gates of your land are wide open for your enemies; fire has ·burned [consumed; devoured] the bars of your gates.

14.verse: ·Get enough water before the long war begins [Draw water for the siege]. Make your defenses strong! Get mud, mix clay, ·make bricks [strengthen the brickwork]!

15.verse: There the fire will ·burn you up [consume/devour you]. The sword will ·kill you [cut you down]; ·like grasshoppers eating crops, the battle will completely destroy you [it will devour you like locusts]. Grow in number like ·hopping [or young] locusts; grow in number like ·swarming [or flying] locusts!

16.verse: Your ·traders [merchants] are more than the stars in the sky, but like locusts they ·strip the land [or shed their skin] and then fly away.

17.verse: Your guards are like locusts. Your officers are like swarms of locusts that ·hang [settle; encamp] on the walls on a cold day. When the sun comes up, they fly away, and no one knows where they have gone.

18.verse: King of Assyria, your ·rulers [shepherds] are asleep; your ·important men [nobles; officers] lie down ·to rest [or dead]. Your people have been scattered on the mountains [like sheep], and there is no one to ·bring them back [gather them].

19.verse: Nothing can heal your wound; your ·injury [wound] ·will not heal [is fatal]. Everyone who hears ·about you applauds [will clap their hands over you], because ·everyone has [who has not…?] felt your endless cruelty.
